div.p: This paper investigates the adaptive fuzzy decentralized fault-tolerant control problem for a class of nonlinear largescale systems in strict-feedback form. The considered nonlinear system contains the unknown nonlinear functions, unmeasured states and actuator faults, which are modeled as both loss of effectiveness and lock-in-place. With the help of fuzzy logic systems to approximate the unknown nonlinear functions, and a fuzzy adaptive observer is designed to estimate the unmeasured states. By combining the backstepping technique with the nonlinear fault-tolerant control theory, a novel adaptive fuzzy decentralized faults-tolerant control (FTC) scheme is developed. It is proved that the proposed control approach can guarantee that all the signals of the resulting closed-loop system are bounded and the tracking errors between the system outputs and the reference signals converge to a small neighborhood of zero by appropriate choice of the design parameters. Simulation results are provided to show the effectiveness of the control approach.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: I N the past decade, fuzzy logic systems (FLSs) and neural networks (NNs) have been extensively used for the modelling and controller design for uncertain nonlinear systems [1][2][3][4][5][6][7] due to their approximation ability to the nonlinear smooth functions, and various adaptive fuzzy and NN decentralized control approaches have been developed for uncertain large-scale nonlinear systems, for example see [8][9][10][11][12][13][14] and the references therein. [8]- [11] developed adaptive NN and fuzzy decentralized state feedback control schemes for some classes of uncertain nonlinear large-scale systems. [12]- [14] proposed adaptive decentralized fuzzy output feedback control approaches for the uncertain nonlinear large-scale systems with immeasurable states. Generally, these adaptive fuzzy and NN decentralized control approaches can deal with a larger class of nonlinear large-scale systems with unknown nonlinear functions and without a priori knowledge on the interconnections, and can achieve satisfactory control performances. However, the main restriction in the above results is that the considered nonlinear systems must satisfy the so-called matching condition [15]- [17]. Thus they can not be applied to handle those nonlinear large-scale systems without satisfying the matching condition.

To solve the decentralized control problem of the nonlinear large-scale systems without satisfying the matching condition, several adaptive NN and fuzzy decentralized controllers have been developed in [18]- [25] by resorting to the backstepping design technique. The works in [18] and [19] developed adaptive fuzzy and NN decentralized backstepping state feedback control approaches for the uncertain large-scale systems with or without time delays. The works in [20]- [22] investigated adaptive NN decentralized backstepping output feedback controllers for a class of the uncertain large-scale systems without requiring that states are available for controller design, while the works in [23] and [24] considered adaptive fuzzy decentralized output feedback controllers for a class of the uncertain large-scale systems with dynamical uncertainties and unknown control directions. The latest works in [25] extended the above results to a class of stochastic nonlinear large-scale systems without satisfying the matching condition.

Although the adaptive decentralized backstepping control has achieved a great development, the aforementioned control approaches assume that all the components of the considered nonlinear large-scale systems are in good operating conditions. As we know, in practical control mechanisms, various components such as actuators, sensors and processors may undergo abrupt failures individually or simultaneously during operation. The adverse effects due to the failures require being compensated and enhance the reliability and safety of the system [26]. It is thus important to develop a FTC scheme accommodating such failures and maintaining acceptable system performance.

In recent years, many effective FTC approaches have been developed to solve the above problems, see for examples [27]- [34] and the references therein. [27]- [28] presented adaptive FTC methods for linear systems with both loss of effectiveness and lock-in-place actuator faults. [29]- [31] developed adaptive FTC methods for a class of single-input and singleoutput(SISO) nonlinear systems and multi-input and multioutput(MIMO) nonlinear systems with the same actuator faults addressed in [27,28], while the works in [32]- [34] developed observer-based adaptive backstepping FTC approaches for some nonlinear systems with additive profile faults. However, the above mentioned FTC schemes all require that the considered nonlinear systems should satisfy the matching conditions or that the nonlinear functions are known or can be linearly parameterized. To remove the above restrictive conditions in [27]- [34], the latest works in [35] and [36] investigated the FTC problem for a class of unknown SISO nonlinear systems in strict-feedback form with both loss of effectiveness and lock-in-place actuator faults, in which fuzzy logic systems are employed to approximate the unknown functions, and new adaptive fuzzy FTC schemes were developed by using the backstepping design technique. The proposed control schemes not only guarantee the stability of the control system, but also obtain the robust control performance. More recently, [37] has extended the results in [35] and [36], and proposed an adaptive fuzzy backstepping FTC scheme for unknown MIMO nonlinear systems in strict feedback form. The main limitation in [35]- [37] is that the states of the controlled systems are required to be measured directly. Thus they can not be applied to solve the problem of those nonlinear large-scale systems with the immeasurable states and actuator failures. It is well known that many practical systems can be described by uncertain large-scale nonlinear systems, and because of the complexity of control design and physical restrictions on the formidable amount of information exchange, it is often required to design a decentralized controller for each subsystem. Compared with the centralized control, the decentralized control is easier to be implemented since the designed control laws for subsystems depend only on local measurements or a minimum amount of information exchange from other subsystems, However, a decentralized controller design is more difficult than that of a centralized control such as [35]- [37]. In addition, since state variables are often immeasurable for many practical nonlinear systems, it is impractical to assume that all subsystem states are available for controller design in some applications as stated in [22]. Therefore, to study the observer-based adaptive decentralized fuzzy FTC for nonlinear large-scale systems with the actuator failures and immeasurable states is very crucial for control theory as well as the synthesis of practical control systems.

It should be mentioned in recent years, several observerbased fuzzy output feedback FTC approaches have been developed in [38]- [45] for the nonlinear systems with actuator faults. However, unlike this paper, the actuator failures in [38]- [45] are the additive profile faults, not the types of the actuators faults considered in this paper. Moreover, the proposed fuzzy FTC schemes are designed based on fuzzy T-S model control design technique [46]- [51], not based on the adaptive backstepping design technique. Therefore, they can not be applied to those nonlinear large-scale systems without satisfying the matching condition or with the actuator failures considered in this paper.

Motivated by the above observations, in this paper, an adaptive fuzzy decentralized FTC method is developed for a class of uncertain nonlinear large-scale systems with the actuator failures called the loss of effectiveness and lockin-place, and without assuming that the states are available for measurements. With the help of fuzzy logic systems to approximate the unknown nonlinear functions, and a fuzzy adaptive observer is developed to estimate the unmeasured states. Using the designed state observer and combining the backstepping technique, a novel adaptive decentralized fuzzy FTC scheme is constructed. It is shown that the proposed control approach can guarantee that all the signals of the resulting closed-loop system are bounded, and the tracking error converges to a small neighborhood of zero even in the presence of the actuator failures and immeasurable states. Comparing with the existing results, the main contributions of this paper can be summarized as follows: (i) the proposed adaptive fuzzy decentralized FTC approach does not require that the nonlinear functions are known or can be linearly parameterized like [29]- [34]. Instead, it utilizes the fuzzy logic systems to approximate the unknown functions and transforms the considered uncertain nonlinear large-scale system into an uncertain parameterized model. Thus it extended the previous results of [29]- [34]. (ii) the proposed FTC approach can be applied to a class of nonlinear large-scale systems with the actuator failures and without satisfying the matching condition. Note that the same problems are also addressed by [35]- [36]. However, unlike this paper, the adaptive fuzzy FTC methods in [35]- [36] are only for a class of SISO or MIMO nonlinear systems, they can not directly applied to the nonlinear largescale systems considered in this paper due to the presences of the unknown interconnection terms; and (iii) by designing a fuzzy state observer to estimate the unmeasured states, the proposed adaptive decentralized FTC scheme cancels the restrictive assumption imposed in [29][30][31][35][36] that the states are available for the controller design. It is important to note that both unmeasured states and non-matching assumption in this paper make the stability analysis very challenging tasks while proving the stability of decentralized interconnected systems.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSIONS
div.p: This paper has developed an adaptive fuzzy decentralized output feedback FTC method for a class of unknown largescale nonlinear systems with actuator faults and without direct requirement of the states measurement. The considered faults are modelled as both loss of effectiveness and lock-in-place. With the help of fuzzy logic systems to approximate the unknown nonlinear functions, a fuzzy adaptive observer has been designed to estimate the unmeasured states. Combining the backstepping technique with the nonlinear tolerant-fault control theory, a novel adaptive decentralized fuzzy output feedback FTC approach has been developed. It has been proved that the proposed FTC approach can guarantee that all the signals of the resulting closed-loop system are bounded and the tracking error between the system output and the reference signal converges to a small neighborhood of zero even in presence of the actuator failures and unmeasured states. Our further researches will concentrate on how to simplify the proposed adaptive FTC approach by using the dynamic surface control technique and relax the limitation in the proposed adaptive FTC approach that the virtual control gains functions in nonlinear large-scale systems are constants.
